items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College is required to create a yearly Student Success and Support Services Program (3SP) plan in response to the Seymour-Campbell Student Success Act (SCSSA) of 2012. The specific requirements in the SCSSA may be found in California Education Code, Sections 78210-78219. By prompting each California Community Colleges to write a 3SP plan, the legislature’s intent is to “increase California community college student access and success by providing effective core matriculation services, including orientation, assessment and placement, counseling, and other educational planning services, and academic interventions.” Consistent with the premise that student success is the responsibility of not only the student, but also of the institution as a whole, the overriding goal is for colleges to outline a specific plan to provide evidence-based, well-coordinated services that are integrated throughout both student services and instruction. Our efforts to increase student success must also give particular attention to at-risk students and to identifying and addressing issues of equity and disproportionate impact. With these principles in mind, we will coordinate with the Basic Skills and Student Equity Workgroups and the academic, classified, and student senates to develop a framework for cross-campus collaboration and coordination. We also realize that it will be imperative to actively include our part-time employees – whether they are faculty or staff – if our efforts are to be successful.
	 
We continue to work with our office of institutional research to evaluate the effectiveness of our efforts and revise our 3SP plan as appropriate in an ongoing effort to increase student success. This includes analysis through program review and other practices to gather data and evaluate outcomes with respect to orientation, assessment and placement, education plans, interventions for at-risk students, and follow-ups. 
	 
The current credit 3SP plan for 2015-2016 is attached.  It is a draft in that the Planning and Resource Council (PaRC) will not be able to meet and approve the plan until October 7, 2015, at the earliest.  The noncredit 3SP plan will be presented for the governing board's information at the November meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Laureen Balducci, Associate Vice President of Student Services, Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Denise Swett, VP Student Services; Carolyn Holcroft, Academic Senate President

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Contract Education office has developed workforce training programs that are aligned to respond to current labor market information and the strategic needs of local workforce development boards.  Foothill-De Anza CCD has entered into an agreement with the City of San Jose to provide custom workforce training programs.  Based on this agreement and in coordination with the guidelines listed by City of San Jose, the Contract Education office has developed a comprehensive array of not for credit training options that meet the needs of the City of San Jose’s programs. Therefore, Purchasing Services staff worked with the Contract Education office to develop a request for proposals and a scope of work for Employment and Training Service providers to obtain assistance with these services. 
	 
Request for Proposal (RFP) #1740 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on August 31 and September 8, 2015.  The RFP was posted through the FHDA portal on PlanetBids website. The proposals were due on September 18, 2015 and one vendor submitted a response, Henkels and McCoy Training Services. Purchasing Services staff and Jon Rubin, Foothill College Director of Business and Education Partnerships evaluated the response. The response from Henkels and McCoy Training Services was complete and thorough and meets the needs of the College. Henkels and McCoy Training Services provided the same services to other public entities such as the County of Santa Barbara and the County of San Luis Obispo.  
	 
The dollar amount of the contract will be based on the number of trainings provided and the amount of revenue received by the City of San Jose. This contract will be funded by Contract Education and the not-to-exceed amount will be $250,000 for fiscal year 15/16.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services

Bernata Slater, Jon Rubin, Annette Perez

Background and Analysis:
	 
In fall 2014, Foothill College submitted its Midterm Report outlining continued progress on meeting the four recommendations from the 2011 Evaluation Team Report as well as College Planning Agendas. Unfortunately the description for Recommendation 4 contained a broken web link to the evidence showing that the recommendation had been met.  Recommendation 4 was in regards to Student Learning Outcomes (SLOs) and faculty evaluations and was met in fall 2012.  The follow-up visiting team in fall 2012 found:
	 
 "The District and the Faculty Association renegotiated the faculty evaluation process to include  
   faculty participation in the evaluation of SLOs, effective Fall Quarter 2012."   
	 
The Commission wrote on February 11, 2013, to accept the review and assure "the recommendations made by the evaluation team were addressed."
	 
In letters dated February 6 and February 17, 2015, the Commission asked that a revised Midterm Report be sent as well as a Follow Up Report (in fall 2015) so that the Commission could see the evidence and take official action.   In response, Foothill College submitted a revised version of its Midterm Report with a corrected link to the evidence for Recommendation 4 to G. Jack Pond on February 23, 2015.  This item includes the Follow Up Report due to the Commission by October 15, 2015.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The California Community College Chancellorâs Office (CCCCO) and the California Department of Education have $500 million appropriated through the State Budget to allocate funding for adult education. The funds will be provided to eligible consortia for the purpose of implementing regional plans for adult education. The intent of the Adult Education Block Grant was to expand and improve the provision of adult education via these consortia. (http://aebg.cccco.edu/About)
	 
Language from the May 15, 2015 Governor Budget Trailer Bill specifically addresses the procedural operations of the AB 86 regional consortia.
	 
05/13/15 02:33PM
RN 15 15041 03 PAGE 1
An act to add article 9 (commencing with Section 84900) to Chapter 5 of Part 50 of Division 7 of Title 3 of and to repeal Section 84908 of, the Education Code, relating to adult education, to take effect immediately, bill related to the budget.
	 
84905. The chancellor and Superintendent, with concurrence of the Executive director, shall approve, for each consortium, rules and procedures that adhere to all of the following conditions:
(a) Any community college district, school district, or county office of education located within the boundaries of the adult education region shall be permitted to join the consortium as a member.
(b) As a condition of joining the consortium, a member shall commit to reporting any funds available to that member for the purposes of education and workforce services for adults and the uses of those funds.
(c) A member of the consortium shall be represented only by an official designated by the governing board of the member.
	 
In order to meet the conditions set forth in the Education Code 84905(c), the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees shall pass a resolution to officially designate Paul Starer, Foothill Division Dean Language Arts and Learning Resource Center, to act on its behalf as the Foothill representative and Thomas Ray, De Anza Division Dean Language Arts, to act on its behalf as the De Anza representative to the North Santa Clara County Student Transition Consortium with voting privileges as they pertain to regional consortium governance.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Both De Anza College and Foothill College are seeking services to revamp and redesign the individual college websites.  The websites are one of the most important marketing, recruitment, and community relations’ tools for students, potential students, staff, and the community at large, yet they are difficult to navigate through and are outdated. The Marketing/Public Relation and Communications departments at each campus worked directly with each other and Purchasing Services staff to develop a Request for Proposal (RFP) that would encompass the desired services required to complete the website redesigns.  
					 
Request for Proposal (RFP) #1716 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on June 24 and July 1, 2015.  Several vendors also received notification that they could download the RFP documents through Foothill-De Anza’s Purchasing web page. Proposals were due on July 31, 2015, and five vendors submitted responses.  
					 
Each campus formed a selection committee consisting of marketing/communications office personnel to evaluate the proposals.  
					 
Upon initial evaluation of the proposals, the Foothill College selection committee identified two vendors to move forward in an interview process; mStoner and VisionPoint Marketing (VisionPoint).  At the conclusion of the interviews, it was determined that VisionPoint earned the highest rank score and the selection committee recommends that the District enter into a contract with VisionPoint for the Foothill College Website Redesign Services. Andrea Hanstein, Director of Marketing & Public Relations, negotiated final details and the fees based upon the pricing and proposal submitted in the RFP for a total amount not to exceed $152,904.00.  The Foothill College Website Redesign Services will be paid for with District enrollment stimulus funds, the Marketing/Public Relations Department budget, and also collegewide funds.
					 
The De Anza College selection committee identified three vendors to move forward in its interview process:  mStoner, NewCity, and VisionPoint Marketing. Upon completion of the interviews and scoring the RFP responses, the committee consensus is to recommend that the District also enter into a contract with VisionPoint Marketing for the De Anza College Website Redesign Services. Purchasing staff and Marisa Spatafore, Associate Vice President of Communications & External Relations, negotiated final details regarding the project management and the fees based upon the pricing and proposal submitted in the RFP.  The Website Redesign Services for De Anza College, in an amount not to exceed $152,904.00 will be paid for with District enrollment stimulus funds, the Communications Department budget, and also collegewide funds.
					 
The contracts will follow the district's standard Agreement for Services format. 
					 
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Andrea Hanstein, Marisa Spatafore, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
  No
